question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
Psychology has been / defined the scientific study of / human psyche and behaviour.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 9 Nov Shift-1)
option_3: defined the scientific study of
solution:
Answer: 3 (defined the scientific study of)

Solution (Correct Option - 3: defined the scientific study of):
The phrase “has been defined the scientific study” is grammatically incorrect.
After “has been”, we need a past participle + by someone structure (passive voice), or the verb must be in the active voice if followed by a direct object.

Correct structure:
Psychology has been defined as the scientific study of human psyche and behaviour.
The verb “defined” needs the preposition “as” after it in this context.

Difficult Word Meanings:
Psychology – the study of the human mind and behaviour (मनोविज्ञान)
Psyche – the human soul, mind, or spirit (मनोबल, आत्मा)

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
He took a hurried glance / on the newspaper / and swiftly left for work.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 9 Nov Shift-3)
option_2: and swiftly left for work
option_3: He took a hurried glance
solution:
Answer: 1 (on the newspaper)

Solution:
The error lies in the preposition “on” in the phrase “glance on the newspaper”.

The correct preposition to use with “glance” is “at”, not “on”.

✔ Correct sentence:
"He took a hurried glance at the newspaper and swiftly left for work."

Why other options are correct:

  • He took a hurried glance – grammatically correct.

  • And swiftly left for work – correct structure and tense.

  • No error – incorrect choice, as there is a clear prepositional error.

Difficult Word Meaning:
Glance at – to look briefly (झलक देखना)
Hurried – done quickly (जल्दबाज़ी में)

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
The ancient trees of this forest did not propagate in the release of seeds.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
solution:
The sentence given is:
"The ancient trees of this forest did not propagate in the release of seeds."

Let’s examine the phrase “propagate in the release of seeds.”

  • The verb “propagate” means to reproduce or spread (especially for plants or animals).

  • It is not used with the preposition "in".

  • The correct structure is: "propagate by/through seed dispersal" or "propagate by releasing seeds".

So, the error is in option 3: "propagate in", because the preposition "in" is incorrect here.

The corrected version could be:

  • "did not propagate through the release of seeds"

  • or "did not propagate by releasing seeds."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
There were frequent landslides in the Jammu-Srinagar Highway during the monsoons.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
solution:
The error lies in the phrase "in the Jammu-Srinagar Highway". The correct preposition to use with the word “highway” is “on”, not “in.”

  • We say: on the road, on the highway, etc., because movement or events occur on the surface of such pathways.

  • Therefore, it should be: “on the Jammu-Srinagar Highway.”

Correct sentence:
There were frequent landslides on the Jammu-Srinagar Highway during the monsoons.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
We had coffee to the university café last evening.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
solution:
The sentence is:
"We had coffee to the university café last evening."

Let’s examine the phrase "to the university café".

  • The preposition "to" is incorrect here.

  • When referring to a place where an activity occurs (like drinking coffee), we use "at" or "in" depending on context.

The correct version should be:
"We had coffee at the university café last evening."

Let’s check the other parts:

  • "We had coffee" – ✅ Correct.

  • "last evening" – ✅ Correct.

Therefore, the error is in part 3: "to the university café"
It should be "at the university café".

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
I was with the impression that I had returned the books that I had borrowed from you.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
option_1: I was with the impression
option_3: the books that I had
solution:
Explanation:

  • The phrase "I was with the impression" is grammatically incorrect.

  • The correct expression is "I was under the impression".

  • Example: I was under the impression that I had returned the books.

Correct Sentence:
I was under the impression that I had returned the books that I had borrowed from you.

question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error.
Mona took a little time to thought before she gave her consent to the proposal.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
option_1: before she gave her consent
solution:
Solution

Erroneous segment: “time to thought”

What’s wrong and why:

  • The verb “took” in the phrase “took a little time to thought” is correctly indicating the act of spending time. However, the infinitive “to thought” is ungrammatical because one does not “time to think” in this construction.

  • In English, when referring to allowing oneself a moment for consideration, the idiomatic phrase is “time for thought”. Here, “for” functions as a preposition introducing the noun “thought”, meaning reflection or consideration.

Correct usage:

  • “Time for thought” – indicates a period set aside for thinking or reflecting.

  • Alternatively, one could say “took a little time to think,” using the verb “think” rather than the noun “thought.”

Correct sentence:
Mona took a little time for thought before she gave her consent to the proposal.

question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error.
 The innocent clerk was accused with misappropriating funds of the company.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
solution:
Solution:
The error lies in the segment "was accused with". The verb "accuse" is always followed by the preposition "of", not "with". So, the correct phrase is "was accused of", meaning someone was charged with wrongdoing.
"The innocent clerk" is correct as it properly introduces the subject with an adjective and noun.
"misappropriating funds" is correct because the gerund "misappropriating" correctly follows the preposition and indicates the act of misuse.
"of the company" is also correct as it shows possession and identifies whose funds were misappropriated.
Hence, only the prepositional usage in "was accused with" is incorrect. The corrected sentence is: The innocent clerk was accused of misappropriating funds of the company.

question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error.
She decided to marry him in spite his habit of spending recklessly.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
solution:
Solution:
The segment "in spite his habit" contains a grammatical error.

Correct usage is: "in spite of his habit"

  • The phrase "in spite" must always be followed by "of" when introducing a noun or noun phrase.

  • So the correct sentence should be:
    "She decided to marry him in spite of his habit of spending recklessly."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
The supervisor emphasised on / the need to gather / as much information as possible.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-2)
option_3: as much information as possible
solution:
Solution:

  • The verb "emphasise" is generally not followed by "on".

  • The correct usage is: "The supervisor emphasised the need to gather..." (without "on").

  • Therefore, the error is in the segment: "The supervisor emphasised on."

Answer: (a) The supervisor emphasised on

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
Children were prohibited to attend / the military parade in which / deadly weapons were displayed.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-2)
option_1: Children were prohibited to attend
option_3: the military parade in which
solution:
Solution:

  • The verb "prohibited" is generally followed by "from + -ing" form, not "to + verb."

  • The correct phrase should be: "Children were prohibited from attending the military parade..."

  • Therefore, the error is in the segment: "Children were prohibited to attend."

Answer: (a) Children were prohibited to attend

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains a grammatical error. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
About the end of the month, the financial planning takes an extremely compromising turn.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-2)
option_2: About the end of the month
option_3: takes an extremely compromising turn.
solution:
Solution:

  • The phrase "About the end of the month" is incorrect.

  • The correct phrase should be "Towards the end of the month" or "At the end of the month."

  • Therefore, the error is in the segment: "About the end of the month."

Answer: (b) About the end of the month

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I haven’t / done the work yet. / I do it / later.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-2)
solution:
Explanation:
The sentence is talking about a future action ("I do it later"), but the structure "I do it" is incorrect for expressing future intention in this context.

  • Correct form: "I will do it later."

Correct sentence:
I haven’t done the work yet. I will do it later.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
Everything happened such quickly that I felt dazed.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
solution:
Explanation:

  • The phrase "such quickly" is grammatically incorrect.

  • The correct form should be "so quickly" because:

  • Use "so" before adverbs and adjectives (e.g., so quickly, so fast, so beautiful).

  • Use "such" before noun phrases (e.g., such a mess, such a beautiful moment).

Correct sentence:
"Everything happened so quickly that I felt dazed."

Hence, the error is in option 2.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
The government has declared a public holiday at Monday.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
solution:
Explanation:

The preposition "at" is incorrect here.
We use "on" with days of the week.

Correct sentence:
The government has declared a public holiday on Monday.

  • "at Monday" ❌

  • "on Monday" ✅

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Whether you are seeking solitude or adventure, India’s lesser-known coastal destinations are offering something for everyone.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
option_4: are offering something for everyone
solution:
Explanation:

  • The subject “India’s lesser-known coastal destinations” is third person plural, so it requires correct verb agreement.

  • However, the verb phrase “are offering” is in the present continuous tense, which implies a current ongoing action.

  • But in formal writing and general statements of fact (like this one), we prefer the simple present tense.

Correct sentence:

Whether you are seeking solitude or adventure, India’s lesser-known coastal destinations offer something for everyone.

So, the verb “are offering” should be replaced with “offer”.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
This incredible discovery / unfolding the history / of a time that existed / long before human existence.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
option_3: of a time that existed
solution:
Explanation:

  • The main subject is "This incredible discovery", which needs a proper verb to complete the sentence.

  • "Unfolding the history" is a present participle phrase, but here we need a finite verb (like "unfolds" or "has unfolded") to form a grammatically complete sentence.

Corrected version:

"This incredible discovery unfolds the history of a time that existed long before human existence."

Hence, the error is in segment 4.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
The Pench Tiger Reserve is / one of India's premier tiger reserve / and the first to span two states.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
option_1: and the first to span two states
option_2: one of India's premier tiger reserve
option_3: The Pench Tiger Reserve is
solution:
Explanation:
The error lies in the phrase "one of India's premier tiger reserve."
When we use "one of", it must be followed by a plural noun, because we are referring to one among many.

  • "tiger reserve" (singular) is incorrect

  • The correct phrase should be "tiger reserves" (plural)

Correct sentence:
The Pench Tiger Reserve is one of India's premier tiger reserves and the first to span two states.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Those people which do not get sufficient sleep at night suffer from a disease called insomnia.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
option_4: Those people which do not get
solution:
Solution:

Sentence:
"Those people which do not get sufficient sleep at night suffer from a disease called insomnia."

Error Identification:

  • The phrase "Those people which..." is incorrect.

  • "Which" is used for things, not for people.

  • The correct relative pronoun for people is "who".

Correct phrase:
"Those people who do not get..."

Corrected sentence:
"Those people who do not get sufficient sleep at night suffer from a disease called insomnia."

Part containing the error: ✅ Those people which do not get (Option 4)

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Passengers started behaving / violent when / they were asked / to leave the bus station.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (01-July Shift 1))
option_4: to leave the bus station.
solution:
The segment containing the grammatical error is:

"violent when"

Explanation: The word "violent" is an adjective, but in this context, the sentence needs an adverb to modify the verb "behaving." The correct adverb form is "violently." So, the corrected sentence would be:

Passengers started behaving violently when they were asked to leave the bus station.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
She w̲i̲l̲l̲ ̲b̲e̲i̲n̲g̲ s̲t̲u̲d̲y̲i̲n̲g̲ for her e̲x̲a̲m̲s̲ t̲o̲m̲o̲r̲r̲o̲w̲.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (04-July Shift 1))
solution:
Answer: 1 (will being)

Explanation:

  • The error is in the verb phrase "will being."

  • "Will" is a modal auxiliary verb that should be followed by the base form of the main verb, which is "be" (verb).

  • The incorrect word "being" is a present participle (verb) wrongly used here.

  • Correction made: Replace "being" with "be" to form the correct future continuous tense "will be studying."

question:
Identify the error in the following sentence and select the option with the correct use of the phrasal verb.
Prateek was planning to ask Shreya for a favour. But he could not muster up the courage. So, he blacked out.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (04-July Shift 3))
option_1: Prateek was planning to ask Shreya for a favour. But he could not muster up the courage. So, he turned down.
option_2: Prateek was planning to ask Shreya for a favour. But he could not muster up the courage. So, he checked out.
option_3: Prateek was planning to ask Shreya for a favour. But he could not muster up the courage. So, he chickened out.
option_4: Prateek was planning to ask Shreya for a favour. But he could not muster up the courage. So, he broke in.
solution:
Answer: 3
Prateek was planning to ask Shreya for a favour. But he could not muster up the courage. So, he chickened out.

Explanation:

  • Chickened out means to lose courage and decide not to do something — fits perfectly here.

  • Turned down means to refuse or reject something — unrelated here.

  • Checked out means to leave or investigate — unrelated.

  • Broke in means to enter forcibly — unrelated.

Hence, the correct phrase is "chickened out."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
I will be study around 7 o’clock.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (04-July Shift 4))
solution:
Answer: 3 (be study)

Solution:
The phrase "be study" is grammatically incorrect. The correct form should be "be studying" or simply "study." Here, the future continuous tense is required: "I will be studying around 7 o’clock."

Part of Speech corrected:

  • Verb form corrected from "be study" (incorrect verb phrase) to "be studying" (present participle for future continuous tense).

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
 A owl is a bird which has wide eyes, asymmetrical ears and is found mostly in forests.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (05-July Shift 3))
option_3: and is found mostly in forests.
option_4: A owl is a bird
solution:
Correct Answer:A owl is a bird

Explanation:

The error lies in the article used before the noun “owl.”

  • “Owl” begins with a vowel sound, so it should be preceded by “an”, not “a.”

Correct form:“An owl is a bird…”

Part of speech corrected:
Article – "A" is replaced with "An" to match the vowel sound at the beginning of "owl."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
‘You expressed your opinion/ very clearly /but I am sorry/ I cannot agree to you’.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (09-July Shift 1))
option_4: I cannot agree to you
solution:
Correct Answer: I cannot agree to you

Explanation:

The error lies in the incorrect use of the preposition "to" after the verb "agree."

  • The correct usage is "agree with someone" and "agree to a proposal/suggestion."

In this sentence, "you" is a person, so the correct phrase should be:
"I cannot agree with you."

Thus, the segment "I cannot agree to you" is grammatically incorrect.

question:
Identify the error in the given sentence and select the correct sentence from the given options.
This is the story of eight round planets, the few rocks in between, and some comets.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (09-July Shift 2))
option_1: This is the story of eight round planets, few rocks in between, and some comets.
option_2: This is the story of eight round planets, a few rocks in between, and some comets.
option_3: This is a story of eight round planets, few rocks in between, and some comets.
option_4: This is story of eight round planets, few rocks in between, and some comets.
solution:
Correct Answer: This is the story of eight round planets, a few rocks in between, and some comets.

Explanation:

  • "This is the story" is correct. We are referring to a specific story.

  • "a few rocks" is the correct phrase.

  • "Few rocks" means almost none (negative sense),

  • "a few rocks" means some, not many (positive sense), which fits the context.

  • Articles like "the" or "a" before “story” are necessary:

  • "This is the story..." is correct.

  • "This is story..." is incorrect (missing article).

  • "This is a story..." is grammatically correct but changes the meaning — “a story” implies one of many; “the story” implies a specific, known one.

✅ Final Answer: This is the story of eight round planets, a few rocks in between, and some comets.

question:
Parts of the given sentence have been underlined. One of them contains an error. The underlined parts are given as options with some changes. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
R̲a̲v̲e̲e̲n̲a̲’̲s̲ ̲d̲a̲u̲g̲h̲t̲e̲r̲ Kavya is m̲o̲s̲t̲ ̲i̲n̲t̲e̲l̲l̲i̲g̲e̲n̲t̲ student and s̲h̲e̲ ̲c̲o̲n̲s̲i̲s̲t̲e̲n̲t̲l̲y̲ achieves t̲o̲p̲ ̲g̲r̲a̲d̲e̲s̲.̲

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (10-July Shift 1))
solution:
Correct Answer: an intelligent

Explanation:
Let’s break down the sentence and examine each underlined part:

  • Raveena’s daughter – ✅ Correct possessive form; refers to the daughter of Raveena.

  • most intelligent student – ❌ Incorrect here. The phrase “most intelligent” must be preceded by an article. Since “most intelligent student” refers to one among many (and is not a superlative comparing all), it should be “an intelligent student”.

  • she consistently – ✅ Grammatically fine and correctly conveys habitual action.

  • top grades – ✅ Correct phrase; common and meaningful.

Only “an intelligent” is the appropriate correction.

So, the correct option is:
an intelligent.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error mark 'No error' as your answer.
Father took the newspaper / in his hand to / go through it once again.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (11-July Shift 1))
option_3: go through it once again
solution:
Correct Answer: No error

Explanation:
The sentence:
"Father took the newspaper in his hand to go through it once again."

is grammatically correct and natural. The phrase "in his hand to go through it" correctly expresses purpose.

  • "Father took the newspaper" – Correct

  • "in his hand to" – Correct

  • "go through it once again" – Correct

Therefore, there is no grammatical error in the sentence.

So, the correct answer is:
No error

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains an error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options.
Select the correct alternative.
Playing ‘hide-n-seek’ is the one of the f̲o̲n̲d̲ memories of my childhood.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.11_08-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct answer: fondest

Explanation:

  • The phrase "the one of the" should be "one of the" (without "the" before one).

  • The underlined word "fond" needs the superlative form because it's referring to "one of the ... memories".

  • The correct superlative of fond is fondest.

  • Other options:

  • fonder – comparative form, incorrect here

  • more fonder – double comparative, incorrect

  • most fondest – double superlative, incorrect

Correct sentence:
"Playing ‘hide-n-seek’ is one of the fondest memories of my childhood."

question:
The given sentence is divided into four segments. Select the option that has the segment with a grammatical error.
I left my / coat in the / hospital when I / had visit Alex.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.11_08-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct answer: had visit Alex.

Explanation:

  • The phrase "had visit Alex" is incorrect because the verb "visit" should be in the past participle form after "had."

  • Correct form: "had visited Alex."

  • Other segments are grammatically correct.

Correct sentence:
"I left my coat in the hospital when I had visited Alex."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Sushil, who recently joined our school / was awarded the Gold Cup / as he worked hardly / throughout the year.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.15_14-Oct_Shift-1)
option_2: was awarded the Gold Cup
option_3: Sushil, who recently joined our school
solution:
Correct Answer: as he worked hardly

Explanation:

  • The phrase "worked hardly" is incorrect.

  • The adverb "hardly" means barely or almost not, which is the opposite of the intended meaning here.

  • The correct adverb should be "hard", which means with a lot of effort.

  • ✅ Correct phrase: "as he worked hard"

So, the segment "as he worked hardly" contains the grammatical error.

question:
The following sentence contains an error. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
Along with his friend, he walked till the end of the street and came back immediately.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.16_14-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Correct Answer: he walked to the

Explanation:

  • The phrase "walked till the end of the street" is grammatically awkward.

  • The correct and more natural usage is "walked to the end of the street".

  • ✅ "To the end" indicates a clear destination or stopping point.

  • The rest of the sentence is correct and needs no change.

Let’s examine the incorrect options:

  • "for came back immediately" – grammatically incorrect.

  • "Near with his friend," – incorrect preposition and awkward phrasing.

  • "end by the street" – illogical; does not convey the intended meaning.

So, the corrected sentence should read:
"Along with his friend, he walked to the end of the street and came back immediately."

question:
The following sentence contains an error. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
His aunt who lives at America brought a lot of gifts for him and his sister.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.17_14-Oct_Shift-3)
option_4: lot of gifts by him
solution:
Correct Answer: in America brought a

Explanation:

  • The original sentence:
    “His aunt who lives at America brought a lot of gifts for him and his sister.”

  • The error is in the preposition "at" — when referring to countries, the correct preposition is "in".

  • ✅ Correct phrase: "lives in America"

Let’s examine the incorrect options:

  • "His aunt which lives" – incorrect relative pronoun; "who" is correct for people.

  • "and her sister" – would change the meaning; the original "his sister" is correct.

  • "lot of gifts by him" – incorrect and ungrammatical.

Therefore, the correct rectification is: in America brought a.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
Alaska in the USA / is the colder / of all the states.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.17_14-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct Answer:is the colder

Explanation:

  • The sentence is making a superlative comparison (comparing Alaska with all other states).

  • The phrase "is the colder" is incorrect because "colder" is the comparative form, used for comparing two things.

  • ✅ The correct superlative form is "coldest".

Correct sentence:
"Alaska in the USA is the coldest of all the states."

Let’s check the other parts:

  • "Alaska in the USA" – correct.

  • "of all the states." – correct.

  • "No error" – not correct, since there is an error.

Thus, the segment "is the colder" contains the error.

question:
Select the sentence that has a grammatical error.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.20_15-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: She always cuts out unhealthy snacks.
option_2: The manager cuts the discussion to address an urgent matter.
option_3: Can you cut through the traffic to get here on time?
option_4: They need to cut down the old tree in the garden.
solution:
Correct Answer: The manager cuts the discussion to address an urgent matter.

Explanation:
The verb "cuts" is incorrect in this context. The correct phrasal verb should be "cut short" (meaning to stop or interrupt something earlier than expected).

Correct sentence: The manager cut short the discussion to address an urgent matter.

All other sentences correctly use phrasal verbs:

  • cuts out = removes

  • cut through = find a quicker path

  • cut down = fell or remove a tree

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Please bring two bananas and the piece of cake from the market.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.23_16-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: and the piece of cake
solution:
Answer: and the piece of cake

Explanation:
The error lies in the phrase "and the piece of cake."

When you're referring to a specific quantity of a countable food item like cake, the correct article depends on the context. But here, the error is in using "the" before "piece of cake" when it hasn't been mentioned earlier in the conversation or context.

It would be more natural and grammatically correct to say:
"a piece of cake" instead of "the piece of cake", unless a specific piece has already been referred to.

Corrected sentence:
"Please bring two bananas and a piece of cake from the market."

question:
Select the sentence that has a grammatical error.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.23_16-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: This is a very difficult task to accomplish.
option_2: I wish I had eraser to erase all the mistakes in my life.
option_3: A young boy offered her his seat.
option_4: I have a lot of work to complete.
solution:
Answer: I wish I had eraser to erase all the mistakes in my life.

Explanation:
The sentence is missing an article before the word "eraser". Since "eraser" is a singular countable noun, it must be preceded by "an" (because it starts with a vowel sound).

Correct sentence:
"I wish I had an eraser to erase all the mistakes in my life."

Other sentences are grammatically correct:

  • "This is a very difficult task to accomplish." – ✅ Correct

  • "A young boy offered her his seat." – ✅ Correct

  • "I have a lot of work to complete." – ✅ Correct

So, the sentence with the grammatical error is:
"I wish I had eraser to erase all the mistakes in my life."

question:
Read the sentence given below and identify if there is an error in it. The error can be in any segment of the sentence which are marked A, B, C, and D. Select option D if there is 'No error'.
(A) She sings / (B) the song / (C) beautiful in the party / (D) No error.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.26_17-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: C

Explanation:
The error is in segment (C) "beautiful in the party".

  • The correct sentence should be:
    "She sings the song beautifully in the party."

  • "Beautiful" is an adjective and cannot describe the verb "sings." We need the adverb "beautifully."

Other segments are correct.

So, the error is in segment C.

question:
Which of the following sentences contains an error in the use of a phrasal verb?

(SSC MTS 2024 S.3_30-Sep_Shift-3)
option_1: It is wise to put up with one's quarrelsome neighbours.
option_2: Can you please take care for my belongings for some time?
option_3: Let's call off the picnic as there is a possibility of heavy rain.
option_4: While visiting the library, I came across an interesting book.
solution:
Correct answer:Can you please take care for my belongings for some time?

Explanation:

Let’s examine each sentence for correct use of phrasal verbs:

  • It is wise to put up with one's quarrelsome neighbours.
    – ✅ "Put up with" means to tolerate. Correct usage.

  • Can you please take care for my belongings for some time?
    – ❌ Incorrect. The correct phrase is "take care of", not "take care for".
    – "Take care for" is not a valid phrasal verb.

  • Let's call off the picnic as there is a possibility of heavy rain.
    – ✅ "Call off" means to cancel. Correct usage.

  • While visiting the library, I came across an interesting book.
    – ✅ "Came across" means to find by chance. Correct usage.

So, the sentence with the incorrect phrasal verb is:
"Can you please take care for my belongings for some time?"
It should be: "take care of."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
A Gita is considered / to be a dialogue between / the Pandava prince, Arjuna, / and Lord Krishna.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.3_30-Sep_Shift-3)
option_1: to be a dialogue between
solution:
Correct answer:A Gita is considered

Explanation:

  • The error is in the use of the article "A" before "Gita."

  • "The Gita" (short for The Bhagavad Gita) is a specific, well-known text, so it should be preceded by the definite article "the."

Let’s evaluate each segment:

  • A Gita is considered – ❌ Incorrect. Should be "The Gita is considered"

  • To be a dialogue between – ✅ grammatically correct

  • The Pandava prince, Arjuna – ✅ correct use of apposition

  • And Lord Krishna – ✅ correct conjunction use

Correct sentence:
"The Gita is considered to be a dialogue between the Pandava prince, Arjuna, and Lord Krishna."

So, the segment "A Gita is considered" contains the error.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
The team with a high motivation level succeeded in its project despite of the challenges it faced.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.32_21-Oct_Shift-3)
option_2: despite of the challenges it faced.
solution:
Answer: despite of the challenges it faced.

Explanation:

  • The phrase "despite of" is incorrect. The correct phrase is "despite" without "of."

  • So, the sentence should say:
    "The team with a high motivation level succeeded in its project despite the challenges it faced."

  • Other parts of the sentence are grammatically correct.

Correct phrase:
"despite the challenges it faced."

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains an error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options.
Select the correct alternative.
Mary is the q̲u̲i̲e̲t̲e̲r̲ student of the class.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.33_22-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: quietest

Explanation:
The sentence is trying to express the superlative degree of the adjective "quiet," since Mary is being compared to all students in the class.

  • Quietest is the correct superlative form of "quiet."

  • Most quiet is sometimes used, but quietest is preferred and more common for short adjectives like "quiet."

  • More quiet is comparative, not superlative, so incorrect here.

  • Quiet (positive form) does not show comparison.

Correct sentence:
"Mary is the quietest student of the class."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
You have spoilt / the little chance you / had at succeeding.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.40_28-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer:No error

Explanation:
The sentence is grammatically correct and does not require any correction.

  • "You have spoilt" – correct present perfect tense; “spoilt” is the British English past participle of "spoil."

  • "the little chance you had" – correctly expresses a small opportunity that existed in the past.

  • "had at succeeding" – while less formal than “had to succeed” or “had of succeeding,” this usage is still acceptable and idiomatic in modern English. It follows structures like:

  • "He had a shot at winning."

  • "She had a chance at escaping."

So, the phrase "had at succeeding" is acceptable and does not constitute a grammatical error.

Final sentence:
You have spoilt the little chance you had at succeeding. ✅

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The dog / eager wagged / its tail when / it saw its owner.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.43_29-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer:eager wagged

Explanation:
The error is in the phrase "eager wagged."

Here, "eager" is an adjective, but we need an adverb to describe how the dog wagged its tail. The correct adverb form of "eager" is "eagerly" – उत्साहपूर्वक.

Correct phrase:eagerly wagged

Correct sentence:
The dog eagerly wagged its tail when it saw its owner.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Despite the challenges, / the team is determined to / completed / the project on time and within budget.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.45_30-Oct_Shift-1)
option_3: the project on time and within budget
option_4: the team is determined to
solution:
Answer:completed

Explanation:
The phrase "determined to" must be followed by the base form of the verb, not the past tense.

  • Incorrect: determined to completed → ❌

  • Correct: determined to complete → ✅

Correct sentence:
Despite the challenges, the team is determined to complete the project on time and within budget.

So, the grammatical error is in the segment "completed".

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
As he is not satisfied / with the jury’s decision, / he appeal / in the higher court.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.51_05-Nov_Shift-1)
option_3: as he is not satisfied
solution:
Answer: c) he appeal

Explanation:
The verb "appeal" in the third-person singular should be "appeals" to agree with the subject "he."

Correct form: "he appeals"

Other segments are grammatically correct.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
She often goes for a walk / with her dog / in the night.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.54_11-Nov_Shift-1)
option_4: She often goes for a walk
solution:
Answer: a) in the night

Explanation:
The phrase "in the night" is incorrect in this context. The correct phrase to indicate regular activity during nighttime is "at night".

Correct sentence:
"She often goes for a walk with her dog at night."

Other parts are grammatically correct.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Our team lost the game / only because of / a mistake / with one of our players.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.55_11-Nov_Shift-2)
option_2: with one of our players
option_3: Our team lost the game
solution:
Answer: b) with one of our players

Explanation:
The phrase "with one of our players" is incorrectly used here.
The correct preposition to indicate the cause related to a player is "by" or "made by" rather than "with."

Correct sentence:
"Our team lost the game only because of a mistake made by one of our players."

  • "with one of our players" incorrectly suggests accompaniment, not cause.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
My mother is 51 years old, / and my uncle is 48 years old. / So my mother is old than my uncle.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.55_11-Nov_Shift-2)
option_1: My mother is 51 years old,
option_2: So my mother is old than my uncle.
option_4: and my uncle is 48 years old.
solution:
Answer: So my mother is old than my uncle.

Explanation:
The error is in the phrase "old than".
The correct comparative form is "older than" when comparing ages.

Correct sentence:
"So my mother is older than my uncle."

question:
Select the sentence that has a grammatical error.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.56_11-Nov_Shift-3)
option_1: Can you bring me the keys to the car?
option_2: They have an information about the event.
option_3: The cat is sleeping on a mat.
option_4: She is an artist at a local gallery.
solution:
Answer: b) They have an information about the event.

Explanation:
The word "information" is an uncountable noun and does not take the article "an".
Correct sentence: "They have information about the event."
Other sentences are grammatically correct.
